question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
I have a spinner that lands on 1 with a probability of $\frac{1}{10}$, 2 with a probability of $\frac{2}{10}$, 3 with a probability of $\frac{3}{10}$, and 4 with a probability of $\frac{4}{10}$. If Phil and Sarah both spin the spinner, what is the probability that they get the same number?
inference:
Let $P(1)$ be the probability that the spinner lands on 1, $P(2)$ be the probability that the spinner lands on 2, $P(3)$ be the probability that the spinner lands on 3, and $P(4)$ be the probability that the spinner lands on 4.
$P(1) = \frac{1}{10}$
$P(2) = \frac{2}{10}$
$P(3) = \frac{3}{10}$
$P(4) = \frac{4}{10}$
The probability that Phil spins the spinner and lands on 1 is $\frac{1}{10}$.
The probability that Phil spins the spinner and lands on 2 is $\frac{2}{10}$.
The probability that Phil spins the spinner and lands on 3 is $\frac{3}{10}$.
The probability that Phil spins the spinner and lands on 4 is $\frac{4}{10}$.
The probability that Sarah spins the spinner and lands on 1 is $\frac{1}{10}$.
The probability that Sarah spins the spinner and lands on 2 is $\frac{2}{10}$.
The probability that Sarah spins the spinner and lands on 3 is $\frac{3}{10}$.
The probability that Sarah spins the spinner and lands on 4 is $\frac{4}{10}$.
The probability that Phil and Sarah get the same number is the sum of the probabilities that they both land on 1, both land on 2, both land on 3, and both land on 4.
$P(\text{same number}) = P(1 \text{ and } 1) + P(2 \text{ and } 2) + P(3 \text{ and } 3) + P(4 \text{ and } 4)$
$P(1 \text{ and } 1) = P(1) \times P(1) = \frac{1}{10} \times \frac{1}{10} = \frac{1}{100}$
$P(2 \text{ and } 2) = P(2) \times P(2) = \frac{2}{10} \times \frac{2}{10} = \frac{4}{100}$
$P(3 \text{ and } 3) = P(3) \times P(3) = \frac{3}{10} \times \frac{3}{10} = \frac{9}{100}$
$P(4 \text{ and } 4) = P(4) \times P(4) = \frac{4}{10} \times \frac{4}{10} = \frac{16}{100}$
$P(\text{same number}) = \frac{1}{100} + \frac{4}{100} + \frac{9}{100} + \frac{16}{100} = \frac{1+4+9+16}{100} = \frac{30}{100} = \frac{3}{10}$
Final Answer: $\boxed{\frac{3}{10}}$
ground_truth: This problem requires a little bit of casework.  There are four ways in which they can both get the same number: if they both get 1's, both get 2's, both get 3's or both get 4's. The probability of getting a 1 is $\dfrac{1}{10}$, so the probability that they will both spin a 1 is $\left(\dfrac{1}{10}\right)^2=\dfrac{1}{100}$. Similarly, the probability of getting a 2 is $\dfrac{2}{10}$, so the probability that they will both spin a 2 is $\left(\dfrac{2}{10}\right)^2=\dfrac{4}{100}$, the probability of getting a 3 is $\dfrac{3}{10}$, so the probability that they will both get a 3 is $\left(\dfrac{3}{10}\right)^2=\dfrac{9}{100}$ and the probability of getting a 4 is $\dfrac{4}{10}$, so the probability that they will both get a 4 is $\left(\dfrac{4}{10}\right)^2=\dfrac{16}{100}$. So our answer is $\dfrac{1}{100}+\dfrac{4}{100}+\dfrac{9}{100}+\dfrac{16}{100}=\frac{30}{100}=\boxed{\dfrac{3}{10}}$.

ground_truth: This problem requires a little bit of casework.  There are four ways in which they can both get the same number: if they both get 1's, both get 2's, both get 3's or both get 4's. The probability of getting a 1 is $\dfrac{1}{10}$, so the probability that they will both spin a 1 is $\left(\dfrac{1}{10}\right)^2=\dfrac{1}{100}$. Similarly, the probability of getting a 2 is $\dfrac{2}{10}$, so the probability that they will both spin a 2 is $\left(\dfrac{2}{10}\right)^2=\dfrac{4}{100}$, the probability of getting a 3 is $\dfrac{3}{10}$, so the probability that they will both get a 3 is $\left(\dfrac{3}{10}\right)^2=\dfrac{9}{100}$ and the probability of getting a 4 is $\dfrac{4}{10}$, so the probability that they will both get a 4 is $\left(\dfrac{4}{10}\right)^2=\dfrac{16}{100}$. So our answer is $\dfrac{1}{100}+\dfrac{4}{100}+\dfrac{9}{100}+\dfrac{16}{100}=\frac{30}{100}=\boxed{\dfrac{3}{10}}$.
